instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.C6990: What is C6990? Capacitor to ground on input to PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H power supply turns 18.5v from charger or 8.5v-12.5v PPBUS_G3H from the battery into PP3V42_G3H. This capacitor can short to ground and keep PP3V42_G3H from turning on which would keep the machine from having a light on the magsafe charger.
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message:
The machine arrived with no ssd and smelling of shampoo but no corrosion.
No idea where to start as I haven't worked on these before.

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 5V = 19kohm to gnd
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = -0.023v = 45kohm to gnd
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0v = 1.5Mohm to gnd
F7000 = ok
measured current resistors <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> 21 22 and <RESISTOR>R7060</RESISTOR> 61 62 all measure within spec

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message: No corrosion so take it to Apple, this is within warranty. But if you insist, is <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message: Its pretty obvious that there has been liquid in the case though,  <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>  = 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message:
No signs of corrosion

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> = 4.95v
<RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR> = 5.2ohm
pin1 = 2.32v
pin2 = 2.28v

<CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> looks to have been replaced

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No power
threads.message: Voltage on <RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR> is probably not right but have nothing to compare. <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is suspect. If the <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> is anything like the <CHIP>ISL95530</CHIP> you are fucked as they have some firmware.
